qas.question: Where did Russian explorers first reach North America?
When did Russian explorers first reach North America?
When did the US buy Alaska?
What portion of Russian-speaking Americans are ethnic Russians?
What is the term for Russian-speaking people?
What did New York buy in the 1700's?
When did explorers from North America first reach Russia?
What is the term for Jews living in Russia?
How many Jews lived in Russia in the 1700's?
In what year did Central Asians immigrate to Russia?

context: The language was first introduced in North America when Russian explorers voyaged into <a0_0><b5_0>Alaska<b5_0/><a0_0/> and claimed it for Russia during the <a1_0><b6_0>1700s<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Although most colonists left after the United States bought the land in <a2_0>1867<a2_0/>, a handful stayed and preserved the Russian language in this region to this day, although only a few elderly speakers of this unique dialect are left. Sizable Russian-speaking communities also exist in North America, especially in large urban centers of the U.S. and Canada, such as New York City, Philadelphia, Boston, Los Angeles, Nashville, San Francisco, Seattle, Spokane, Toronto, Baltimore, Miami, Chicago, Denver and Cleveland. In a number of locations they issue their own newspapers, and live in ethnic enclaves (especially the generation of immigrants who started arriving in the early <b9_0>1960s<b9_0/>). Only <a3_0>about 25%<a3_0/> of them are ethnic Russians, however. Before the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the overwhelming majority of <a4_0><b7_0>Russophones<b7_0/><a4_0/> in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn in New York City were Russian-speaking Jews. Afterward, the influx from the countries of the former Soviet Union changed the statistics somewhat, with ethnic Russians and Ukrainians immigrating along with some more Russian Jews and Central Asians. According to the United States Census, in 2007 Russian was the primary language spoken in the homes of <b8_0>over 850,000<b8_0/> individuals living in the United States.
